pullRequest.body:
Most of the theory in `LinearAlgebra/QuadraticForm/Basic` also holds for Quadratic Maps with minimal modification. A quadratic form is just a special case of a quadratic map.

To keep this PR to a reasonable size I have not attempted to generalise other files in `LinearAlgebra/QuadraticForm` - this can be done in subsequent PRs.

To facilitate dot notation we also introduce `LinearMap.BilinMap` as an abbreviation for `M →ₗ[R] M →ₗ[R] N`. No attempt has been made to generalise all `BilinForm` results to `BilinMap` at this stage.

Some results in `LinearAlgebra/QuadraticForm/Basic` are still stated for quadratic forms either because there was no obvious generalisation to quadratic maps, or the generalisation requires improvements elsewhere in Mathlib which can be considered in subsequent PRs.

My motivation for introducing Quadratic Maps to Mathlib is that it would allow the definition of interesting non-associative structures such as quadratic Jordan Algebras and Jordan Pairs.

---

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

-->

nodes.body: Having thought some more, I think the non-commutative case should be $Q(ax) = aQ(x)a^*$ (making $x \mapsto xx^\*$ a quadratic form), but I don't think we should worry about that until someone asks for it

> Having thought some more, I think the non-commutative case should be Q(ax)=aQ(x)a∗ (making x↦xx∗ a quadratic form), but I don't think we should worry about that until someone asks for it

I had that thought too - the polar would be a [σ-sesquilinear form](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/SesquilinearForm.lean).

bors d+

Thanks again for your patience here!

Please look over @MichaelStollBayreuth's suggestions above, and reword the docstrings where appropriate.

The performance doesn't look great (especially impacting files that I spend time on!), but I think this is likely just an unavoidable cost of generality, and so we don't need to worry about it for now.

:v: mans0954 can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9921731734/job/27410011004)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9921731734/job/27410011232)
Thanks for the contribution. I have read through everything once; I might do it again tomorrow.
Thanks for the contribution. I have read through everything once; I might do it again tomorrow.

Some initial comments; this generally looks great, but there a few places where the `abbrev`s seem to be causing dot notation trouble. I'll try to check things out in VSCode to see what's going on, in a few days.

This feels a bit like this is trying to be a quadratic map over a bimodule, which IMO is a little awkward given that we don't even have linear maps over a bimodule!

Do you actually need to support a non-commutative `R` here? I don't know if even the current definition makes any sense when R is not commutative.

> This feels a bit like this is trying to be a quadratic map over a bimodule, which IMO is a little awkward given that we don't even have linear maps over a bimodule!

Yes, I got the idea for how to do this from https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Bimodule.lean

> Do you actually need to support a non-commutative `R` here? I don't know if even the current definition makes any sense when R is not commutative.

Personally I'd be quite happy with `R` commutative. The current `QuadraticForm` definition uses `R` non-commutative. So the possibilities are:

1. Develop `QuadraticMap` and `QuadraticForm` as separate (but very similar) theories, with the former over a commutative ring and the latter over a non-commutative ring
2. Have `QuadraticForm` as a special case of `QuadraticMap`, but both over a commutative ring
3. Figure out how to make `QuadraticForm` work over a non-commutative ring

I guess there is also the option of starting off with `QuadraticForm` work over a non-commutative ring and then specialising to commutative when we need to?

I'm starting to like the idea of 2. Maybe that looks like:
* make a PR that ungeneralizes QuadraticForm to commutative rings and see if CI/Zulip cares
* generalize `QuadraticForm` to `QuadraticMap`.
It might be worth asking on Zulip and looking at the git history before embarking on that first point

Looks like the use of non-commutative rings goes back to the PR that originally introduced quadratic forms:

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/2480
I've asked here: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/Quadratic.20Maps

I think we're going to want separate definitions (`polarBilin` and `polarBilinForm`) in the short term.

Note that you can use `LinearMap.mk\2` here to golf this.

I've changed it to use `LinearMap.mk₂`. The def is now
```
def polarBilin : BilinMap R M N
```
where
```
variable (R M Nₗ) in
/-- A shorthand for the type of `R`-bilinear `N`-valued maps on `M`. -/
protected abbrev BilinMap : Type _ := M →ₗ[R] M →ₗ[R] Nₗ

variable (R M) in
/-- For convenience, a shorthand for the type of bilinear forms from `M` to `R`.

This should eventually replace `_root_.BilinForm`. -/
protected abbrev BilinForm : Type _ := LinearMap.BilinMap R M R
```
@eric-wieser following #11278 do we still need a separate `polarBilinForm`?
I think probably not.

```suggestion
theorem map_add_self (x : M) : Q (x + x) = 4 • Q x := by
  rw [← two_smul R x, map_smul, nsmul_eq_smul_cast R]
  norm_num
```
Thanks - that's much better.
This section would be slightly more readable if you used the variable name `M'` instead of `N'`.
Okay, done.

```suggestion
/-- Compose the quadratic map with a linear function on the right. -/
```

This definition does two different things:
1. It pulls back the quadratic map from `R` to `S`.
2. It then composes the quadratic map on the left with the `S`-linear function `f`.

I think each of these should be done with a separate definition.
I've converted `compQuadraticMap` into a composition.

Here is my attempt at making this simpler:

```suggestion
theorem _root_.QuadraticMap.polarBilin_injective (h : IsUnit (2 : R)) :
    Function.Injective (polarBilin : QuadraticMap R M N → _) := by
  intro Q₁ Q₂ h₁₂
  apply h.smul_left_cancel.mp
  rw [show (2 : R) = (2 : ℕ) by rfl]
  simp_rw [← nsmul_eq_smul_cast R, ← QuadraticMap.toQuadraticMap_polarBilin]
  exact congrArg toQuadraticMap h₁₂
```

I prefer `IsUnit` to `Invertible` here. `Invertible` would be acceptable if it was a typeclass argument.

```suggestion
    CanLift (BilinMap R M R) (QuadraticForm R M) (associatedHom ℕ) LinearMap.IsSymm where
```

```suggestion
#align quadratic_form.exists_quadratic_form_ne_zero QuadraticMap.exists_quadraticForm_ne_zero
```

- This section should be in the namespace `QuadraticForm` instead of `QuadraticMap`.
- Every occurrence of `QuadraticMap` in this section should be replaced with `QuadraticForm`.
I've adapted the `PosDef` section so that the results now work for Quadratic Maps.

```suggestion
```

Once again:
- This section should be in the namespace QuadraticForm instead of QuadraticMap.
- Every occurrence of QuadraticMap in this section should be replaced with QuadraticForm.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
theorem separatingLeft_of_anisotropic {B : BilinForm R M} (hB : B.toQuadraticMap.Anisotropic) :
```

The variable name you use here is unfortunate. Change its name.

Every theorem and definition in this section still applies to a matrix whose entries lie in an `R`-module.

```suggestion
  lift B to QuadraticForm R M using hB₂ with Q
```

```suggestion
  ∑ i : ι, w i • (proj (R := R) (n := ι) i i)
```

One final time:
- This section should be in the namespace QuadraticForm instead of QuadraticMap.
- Every occurrence of QuadraticMap in this section should be replaced with QuadraticForm.

```suggestion
/-- For convenience, a shorthand for the type of bilinear forms from `M` to `R`. -/
```
It's possible to have `[NonUnitalNonAssocCommSemiring N]` here - but then `linMulLinSelfPosDef` breaks.
This is being dealt with in #12617 - for now we will stick with the `CommSemiring` case.
Should these be left as `BilinForm` now?

I think I started moving some things into the `BilinMap` namespace to avoid breaking dot notation, but this then leaves a bit of a mishmash of `BilinForm`s and `BilinMap`s. And even with these changes I still ended up breaking dot notation elsewhere. Possibly we need to sort out `BilinForm` / `BilinMap` / (along with the Sesquilinear equivalents) before this PR?
This breakage of dot notation is unfortunate
This dot notation failure is also sad
Probably `map_zero` should be `protected` to avoid this issue. (in a pre-work CL)
I pushed a cleanup.
More dot notation loss
You shouldn't need both `SmulCommClass`es here, as one can be built from the other.

The following MWE:
```
import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Defs

variable {S T : Type*}
variable {R : Type*} {M N : Type*}
variable [Semiring S] [CommSemiring R] [AddCommMonoid N] [Module S N] [Module R N] [SMulCommClass S R N]

instance : SMulCommClass R S N := by infer_instance
```
The `infer_instance` fails with `failed to synthesize instance SMulCommClass R S N`.
Indeed, but you can build it manually; see 3e887927a25ac161c3ecb10b8f306e3324a4e872
Looks like you've fixed this for me now? Thanks.
This definition now feels a little weird; I'll have another look later.
Let's swap these around, and call this one `compQuadraticMap'`, leaving `compQuadraticMap` for the simpler one above.
@eric-wieser do you mean `compQuadraticMapAux` should be renamed to `compQuadraticMap` and `compQuadraticMap` renamed to `compQuadraticMap'`?
Yes
Done.
I think `N` should probably be called `A` or something here, to indicate it is more than a module.
Done, thanks.
Can you split this to its own PR (in the right place), then ask for help with `ring` on zulip?
Done #12617 and https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Adding.20an.20instance.20breaks.20.60Mathlib.2ETactic.2ERing.2EBasic.60
We're restricting `linMulLin` to the `CommSemiring` case for now.
This extra `SMulCommClass` is a bit suspicious
Looks like you've fixed this for me: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7569/commits/3c60a70c7d69cf01cd7d2d6494335d4bc5a93e68 - thanks.

```suggestion
/-- A shorthand for the type of `R`-bilinear `Nₗ`-valued maps on `M`. -/
```
Or should `Nₗ` in the `variable` line (and later) be just `N`?
Let's use `Nₗ` for now rather than messing with the variables. I think `N` is used for semilinear maps in this file.

```suggestion
This file defines quadratic maps on an `R`-module `M`.
```

```suggestion
A quadratic map over a commutative ring `R` is a map `Q : M → N` such that:
```
Add a specification of what `N` is?
This should this be `(a * a) • Q x` on the right; cf. line 144.

```suggestion
* `QuadraticMap.map_smul`: `Q (a • x) = (a * a) • Q x`
```
I don't think the first equality is what is wanted here (this would not be a useful scalar multiplication, as it is not linear in `a`). See line 392.

```suggestion
Quadratic maps come with a scalar multiplication, `(a • Q) x = a • Q x`,
```

```suggestion
/-- A quadratic map on a module.
```

```suggestion
/-- A quadratic form on a module. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- `QuadraticMap R M N` inherits the scalar action from any algebra over `R`.
```

```suggestion
/-- Evaluation on a particular element of the module `M` is an additive map on quadratic maps. -/
```

```suggestion
  LinearMap.ext₂ fun x y => by
    rw [associated_toQuadraticMap, ← h.eq x y, RingHom.id_apply, ← two_mul, ← smul_mul_assoc,
      smul_eq_mul, invOf_mul_self, one_mul]
```
Note that this is the proof term, not part of the statement, so indent by 2 instead of 4.

```suggestion
/-- `M.toQuadraticMap'` is the map `fun x ↦ row x * M * col x` as a quadratic form. -/
```
otherwise the products don't make sense.
